Iuk2WFx1WS0mXbHlEnj4aQ.text: This place serves real good sundulbu and ddok bugi. Note that there is always a queue hence be there early, or be ready to join the beeline.Their free-flow side dishes are really good too. My fav includes the ikan bilis and korean fishcake/beancurd (well-seasoned)

TCe1B2ll7XOToJtsA-dz9A.text: This is the sort of place where cold barley tea is on tap, and you just know there is a Korean grandmother in the kitchen, making everything with love.All I can say is that I don't come often enough, and the grilled belly pork is to die for. Gotta get me a bunch of friends to feast now.

3-FyxMdECXCn5oBAPcA_Yg.text: Authentic korean food! Finally! We had the Yukgaejang, and the flavor was exactly what it should be. There have been so many other korean restaurants that I've tried here in Singapore that just had something missing in their Yukgaejang, but Togi has it right! We also ordered the Japchae and the Kimchi Pancake, which were good too. I find no fault in either dishes. The portions of the dishes were substantial, and the service was fast.

IiM3uyCAcee6fTcgMaq44w.text: This is a Korean cuisine restaurant which provides both BBQ and A-la carte. It is located in China Town, Mosque Street. The operating hour is from 12pm to 9pm and closed on Sundays. I have been here around 8pm with friends; the service is unsatisfied as while we are still eating, the waitress cleans our dishes without asking. I guess they are rushing for closing.We had soondubuchigae (soft tofu stew), ramen and gimpap (korea rice roll, similar to sushi). We were served for 6 side dishes - kimchi, anchovies, cucumbers kimchi, mashed potato, bean curd skin and seasoned vegetables. Even the portion is small for each side dish, but it is refillable on demand, our favour is anchovies and mashed potato. Although the service is bad, we still enjoy the dishes and it is still recommended to those who really like Korean Cuisine.

hkDuQ1b-_YFRlmHQwwvRmA.text: I casually mentioned to my family the whole idea of eating jjajangmyeon on Black Day, which falls on the 14th of April every year. For Koreans, 14th of February is known as Valentine's Day 14th March known as White Day and 14th April Black Day, and these three days are days in which girls give guys chocolates, followed by the guys returning the favour and lastly a day for singles to gather and 'mourn' their singlehood. Although the idea is meant to egg singles to be more open to dating, it still seem to be a fun excuse to gather, as there were many Koreans that day gathering to eat the noodles together. The jjajangmyeon here is really tasty, and comes in two different sizes-the normal serving for one, or two, and a really huge serving big enough to feed five or more people. Eating this black noodles, however, require care. Another must try here is the kimbab (about $12). Beautifully made into teardop shaped  rolls, the kimbabs here are stuffed with succulent ingredients, and the sticky rice holds them all together in place. The owners are Koreans, and hence the food has the authentic delicious taste which is not found in many other Korean-run restaurants.Opening hours: Daily 11.30am - 2.30pm, 6pm - 10pm.

_RZx9Jp_a7ZYL5i02RhoIQ.text: As a Korean expat living in Singapore, I have had difficulty finding authentic Korean restaurants here. I dined at Togi on a Friday night and was thrilled to find a place that: 1) Served boricha  (iced barley tea) instead of water 2) Offered metal utensils in a box on the table 3) Included waitstaff who could dialogue with me in Korean 4) Served a large variety of side dishes that were free flow 5) Offered two of the more arduous soups on the menu (sullungtang & yookgaejang).I tried the sullungtang during this visit and was thrilled. I will definitely return given the quality, service, and location. One of the best Korean restaurants in singapore.

Z4gYiuqBtWzz8Ec8c59jEA.text: Bulgogi ($18) - 3.5 starsToo sweet and too salty! I don't get why this doesn't come with rice. On the plus side there's a lot of meat.Sundubu - 3.5 starsToo salty and not enough soup.Rice ($2/extra bowl)We paid $40+ for the two dishes and 2 extra bowls of rice (we had 3 bowls of rice between the two of us) and a pot of hot tea.I miss my favourite Korean place near LA! The places I've been to in Singapore just don't match up. The ban chan variety is smaller and they somehow taste too salty or like they were bought at a supermarket. And they only have white rice here while the places in LA serve mixed grains. Service could be better - they never seemed to hear us - we had to yell from the table next to the table they were clearing - and when we ordered extra rice they gave it to us with an unpleasant frown. Not sure what I did to offend them.

USHWw5yQVohXpuUVvDutvA.text: Wanted to eat something Korean and after reading the good reviews here, I decided to check this out with my family in tow. We had:Pork Ribs Stew - it's a big pot of steaming stew that has vegetables and mushrooms in them. The waitress who served it would even proceed to remove the meat from the long rib bones for us. So every scope is just with really tender and flavourful pork meat and yummy soup. Excellent with some rice. Spicy Pig Trotters - it's a huge plate of pig trotters that's cut into chunks. I eat only the meaty bits and if you eat it with the lettuce leaves and garlic slices, it's wow wow wow! Not too spicy but has enough kick! Nice!!Bimbimbab - I've heard many people loving this rice combi so I ordered one with spicy pork to try. I'm won't order it again but I can see the draw of this dish. I guess it's not for me. Beef Gravy Soup - this has Korean vermicelli in it. Theirs is thicker than regular Chinese ones. The soup base is actually quite sweet and it really quite a nice dish. My girl loves it!Potato Pancake - this side dish is no side show! It's crispy and really tasty! My other girl loves it so much that she declared that when we return again, she is having 3, all by herself! I support her! HehThey served us 6 side dishes and they are:Kimchi - I don't like kimchi so no commentsPotato Salad - theirs has raisins in them so it's kinda sweet. Theirs also has bits of nut and the overall taste is just great!Garlic Vege - it's simple fare of sauté green vege with garlic but it's so good!Spicy Ikan Bilis - it's sticky and a bit spicy and crunchy with white sesame seeds, how to go wrong?Peanuts - theirs is coated with this sticky black sauce that makes the taste interesting. Nice. Preserved Cucumber - it's refreshingly cold and crunchy too. Reminded me of our local acah. We couldn't finish all our food and the lady boss was happy to pack it for us. Many reviews complained of poor service but while service was not top notch, it's really quite ok. They gave us a 20% voucher for returning customers and we will be definitely be back to use it!

photos.caption: Photo of Togi Korean - Singapore, Singapore. Beef Gravy Soup
Photo of Togi Korean - Singapore, Singapore. Spicy Pig Trotters
Photo of Togi Korean - Singapore, Singapore. Pork Ribs Stew

_E9N7lV_UdsKlxWVMHcEiQ.text: Nice, small restaurant that I visited once while in Singapore. Service wasn't anything special, but the food was really good and came out quickly enough. I'd drop by again if I had nowhere else to go. Overall, a very typical Korean dining experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Togi Korean - Singapore, Singapore. Ramen + ddeokbokki

rZcCc4z_ur4A0eaYeWGepg.text: In my numerous trips to Singapore, I realized that it's pretty damn hard to find a good Korean restaurant.  Don't get me wrong.  There are a lot of Korean restaurants so it's unfair for me to judge all of them collectively.  But I've had my share of disappointments.Togi, on the other hand, did not disappoint.Food ordered:  marinated boneless beef short rib and ramen rice cake (rabboki).Some rice cake pieces were a bit hard and dry.  That costed a star.  But the beef short rib was fantastic.  Tender and not too salty and generous in portion.  That gained half a star but I can't give a 4.5 stars.  For under SGD40, I walked away full and satisfied.

photos.caption: Photo of Togi Korean - Singapore, Singapore. Marinated boneless beef short rib
Photo of Togi Korean - Singapore, Singapore. Rabboki (ramen rice cake)

a2A588o0J3Q0T75z62QT7Q.text: Koreatown was comfort food for me in Manhattan, so now I find myself craving Korean food often in Singapore - especially as it's much cheaper than New York! Togi hit the spot & I'll be back for more spicy soup cravings. I've been to both the Mosque St and the Triple One branch, and I have to say I kind of prefer the Triple One branch: the atmosphere is spacious and airier, and the service is better, for food of similar quality and prices. This Togi is tucked in a street full of predominantly Chinese eateries, with cosy and homely Korean-inspired cutesy decor. It isn't that large - maybe 10 or so tables?- explaining the lines here at night. We went for a late lunch around 1pm and there were only 2-4 tables filled. The kitchen was preparing some takeaway orders too. The soups are the standout here: I'd advise shying away from other dishes. I was a little more "adventurous" today and we shared a kimchi pancake with seafood ($12) and bibimbap ($12) along with my standard order of seafood tofu soup ($13). The seafood tofu soup was, as usual, amazing. Its spiciness had a kick to it, and it included cockles and 2 large prawns (unpeeled! We felt so lazy to peel it at first lol), and a big hunk of silky soft tofu. Some restaurants include kimchi for the spice in the soup, but this tasted more like a chili sort of spice. This soup has never disappointed me. The other two dishes were not great - the kimchi pancake was paper-thin and I could not taste or see any bits of seafood at all. Perhaps a more accurate description is kimchi pancake. If you're craving for seafood, order the seafood pancake ($18) instead, which was terrific when I had it at the Triple One branch, thicker and layered with prawns, squid and so on. The bibimbap was also disappointing - the beef used was ground/minced beef, not beef slices or bulgogi, which made the whole dish quite mushy. There's also a strange flavor to the dish, besides the spiciness of the gochujang, that reminded me of soy? I've never tasted that before in other bibimbaps. Definitely affordable price for a stone bowl bibimbap, though I've tasted better ones at food courts. I intend to try the bossam or bbq next time!

photos.caption: Photo of Togi Korean - Singapore, Singapore. interior
Photo of Togi Korean - Singapore, Singapore. refillable banchan!
Photo of Togi Korean - Singapore, Singapore. kimchi pancake with seafood ($12)

-nRdfLCRmdPwtQV-vwpHhg.text: One of the most authentic Korean food you can get in the area!I had the potato and ribs stew with fried rice after. The fried rice is done in the same pot you had the stew and it's really the Korean way of doing it.The side dishes comes in great variety too! Especially love the spicy ikan bilis - korean style :)Price is actually not bad, i think it pretty affordable as compared to some wannabe Korean restaurants with high price and bad food.It's pretty conveniently located near the subway station too! Will definitely come back and recommend it to any Korean food lovers!

photos.caption: Photo of Togi Korean - Singapore, Singapore. The fried rice after our gamjjatang (or ribs and potato stew).

jhEFmEwvwHq1rDGUh9t-XQ.text: Looking for good, tasty Korean food in Chinatown? Togi can hit the spot.After a morning stroll, I was craving some dukbokki and went here to check it out... yumm! It had more lettuce/greens than what I've had around Seattle but I liked it instead of the usual/authentic(?) goods in the red haze. The rice cakes, fish cakes, other stuff(?)... just good satisfying food to me.The staff was pleasant, space was nice and cool from the weather and would visit again when back in S'pore.

VnavvaCedmzXZFONtbaqRg.text: Went in with high expectations, and Togi met all of them! I was really craving some great Korean style barbeque, but instead went for a Spicy Beef Soup, as well as Kimchi with Pork Belly and oh MY was it amazing.We all agreed that the Kimchi with Porky Belly was the best overall dish. It had the spiciness and taste of Kimchi, as well as a sweetness from the seasoning of the meat, as well as a smokey aftertaste from the barbeque. On top of that the Spicy Beef soup was so beautiful. I want to go back right now and eat it again! The broth was so silky and smooth, and had an amazing taste, that is so good, that I'm lost for words describing it.I am now a huge fan of Togi, and will definitely be visiting again! masisseoyo! :)

nQbWmlsqK-QMZ8dULVhlJA.text: Had the pork ribs stew instead of the usual army stew this time. The ribs were awesome. Tenderly soft and they tasted as good as they smell. The soup was perfect as well, but not your usual kimchi flavor.Definitely recommended! Tip: goes well with some soju!

RLUfVSE9CBbH-WGqFL-gDQ.text: A beautiful, quaint atmosphere that complements the aromatic food perfectly.Delicious, free-flow side dishes and generous portions make Togi a place well worth returning to. Their staff are amazing and well-mannered, not to mention quick and efficient.

08ckwfRFpTrchv_oJ3OL_g.text: The place for me to get a bowl of sundubu whenever I have craving! Yes, no sharing! It is that good!

xl05aTy3Px3l396CbfD0Fw.text: Used to taste authentic but I am not really sure what happened?! This was my third time to be on this place and felt that the standard is declining. The side dishes wasn't as fantastic as before (a big change of taste actually). Their service changed too! Somehow the non-Korean food attendants are impatient and they were a bit pushy on their recommendations. For a friend of mine who is new to this place, he found it so so taste only and for him the price that we paid seem not justifiable for the service and food he experienced.

photos.caption: Photo of Togi Korean - Singapore, Singapore. Boodae Jeongol! An army of ham, tofu,sausages and ramen.

9LeNaTpn1UgmvO1h5WNyaA.text: I always trust the recommendations for Korean cuisine from friends who have been to Korea and Togi was one of them. A family joint for your favourite korean nosh, you can find your bulgogi, ramen, jjajangmyeon, kimchi jigae and more on the extensive menu. I have yet to try everything but I do recommend their tuna kimchi jigae which the general servings and flavourful soup with a good kick. You definitely need to queue if you're down for dinner or be very lucky to be there before a queue starts forming.

photos.caption: Photo of Togi Korean - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Togi Korean - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Togi Korean - Singapore, Singapore

-S_HNZQS98hDxK_RupjY-g.text: Togi is one of my favourite Korean places to dine in when I feel like eating some authentic Korean food. The restaurant is owned by Koreans and you can actually taste the difference with those you order at food courts. Also, if you are a Kpop fan, you get to watch music shows like Music Bank or Inkigayo on their big television screen! Sometimes, they also play popular music videos of idols, which explains the increasing number of teenagers at the restaurant.One of my favourite dishes from Togi is the pancake! Though a simple dish, it's tasty, chewy and full of flavour. Something I will recommend to you! Even the spicy kimchi stew is pretty good. I personally love their kimchi and will even buy a pack to two home!

photos.caption: Photo of Togi Korean - Singapore, Singapore

s7ASs62sn4-nFb9O1EVczw.text: I haven't had good Korean food in a long while, so decided to pop by this restaurant based on a friend's recommendations.Service (by the predominantly Chinese staff) was passable. The side dishes here are free flow (which gave me the same feeling when I had Korean food in Canada). I tried the seafood pancake, which was thick and fluffy. Most importantly, it contained a lot of crunchy seafood that made this pancake such a treat. Next, we tried the kimchi soft tofu stew, which was really delicious and not too spicy. My friend had the ginseng chicken soup, and I had the chance to give it a try as well. The soup was wonderful and definitely not MSG laden, and the chicken portion was generous as well. Finally, we tried the spicy bbq pork, which had a good mix of spiciness and overall very delicious as well.Overall, this is a great place for Korean food!

photos.caption: Photo of Togi Korean - Singapore, Singapore

fq3edV5U9BTA3CWaqdO9JQ.text: Big winners: the chapchae and kimchi pajun were really, really good. The soon doobu had good flavor, but wasn't spicy. I would think that could be easily remedied by asking them to make it extra hot next time. Strangely, they were out of the regular kalbi on the bone, at 7pm on a Saturday night. For such a staple dish, you'd think they'd want to have plenty of it during the peak dinner hour. So we had the boneless kalbi, which was tender but surprisingly under-seasoned/marinated. I wonder if they were just overrun and didn't marinate long enough. Anyway, that was kind of a disappointment. They don't take reservations, so there was a bit of a wait, but no more than 10-15 minutes for a party of four. All in all, I'd go back, but I wasn't blown away.

KEOd53dFEenPk6Q9mOuIsg.text: Everything was just ok. Disappointing after all the good reviews. Cute little place but not cheap enough to justify the mediocre food.

_pSbLv6fNtcVk9JAYBt9VQ.text: This place has the best Soondubujigae (spicy beancurd stew). Really. For 12 bucks, you get a bowl of well seasoned, a little spicy, tofu soup with generous amount of seafood (prawn, clams, squid). An egg is cracked into it as well. Honestly I only need a bowl of this and I can finish a pot of rice. The soup is as good if not better than those I've eaten in Korea.I find it hard to fault any dishes they have here. Seafood pancake is good, grilled pork belly is good, hot pot stew is good too. You should just order everything really. This is my go to place for Korean food anytime. Till I find a better one. :)

Afz-SvHajsjGd0ZYE4nLAw.text: The bulgogi was pretty good. It didn't have any sweet potato glass noodles but there was a lot of meat and it was well-seasoned. The side dishes were also good and bottomless, especially the kimchi, miniature sardines, and green beans. The Kimchi buchimgae was a little thick for my tastes and the haemul pajeon the people sitting next to us ordered was 3 times thicker than usual. The prices were reasonable. We were sitting next to another party of two at a four-person table so it felt like I should have been talking to the person next to me because he was much closer than my date.
